articles.title: Rising temperatures across all 50 U.S. states
articles.author: Adam Strzempko
articles.summary: Temperatures have been rising in all 50 states since the first Earth Day in 1970. In 203 cities analyzed, the temperature has warmed by at least 2 degrees. Burlington, Vermont, was one of the fastest-warming cities across the country. The levels of carbon dioxide and methane are more than 50 percent and 160 percent higher than before.

articles.title: Spring's hot weather to be treat for nature lovers
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: There's a mini-heatwave looming for the UK at the end of April. The warm weather is expected to give a temporary boost to nature as migratory birds arrive from afar and butterflies stretch their wings. The British Trust for Ornithology says a succession of milder winters and wetter springs are contributing to change in the natural world.

articles.title: Spring wave of hot weather to be treat for nature lovers
articles.author: Helen Briggs
articles.summary: Temperatures in the UK are expected to rise to the mid-teens. The warm weather is good for migratory birds and butterflies. The Met Office says it won't affect water sources such as ponds. Conservationists warn that climate change is already having a big impact on our wildlife.

articles.title: More on the mall: drastic action needed to save business and the planet
articles.summary: The temperature has just passed 1.5 degrees and is on its way to 3 degrees. My friends are concerned about climate change but they don't want to hear that we can't make the climate safe if we keep flying. It's the most warming single thing you can do.

articles.title: Delhi records hottest day of year; IMD warns of further rise in temp
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: Delhi recorded its hottest day of the year on Friday, with temperatures soaring to 43.3°C in the Ridge areas and 41.8°C on Lodhi Road. It is the highest maximum for the month of April in three years, surpassing the previous high of 43.5°C recorded on April 28, 2022. The city's air quality also worsened.

articles.title: Watch: Morano on Jesse Watters on blocking the sun with geoengineering
articles.author: Cfact Ed
articles.summary: Marc Morano is the publisher and author of The Great Reset: Global Elites and the Permanent Lockdown. He talks about the scandal at the World Economic Forum and geoengineering. Morano believes the world is changing and people are waking up to the WEF's agenda.

articles.title: Nebraska's High Plains Regional Climate Center back online after brief shutdown
articles.author: Chris Dunker
articles.summary: The High Plains Regional Climate Center went offline on April 17 after its funding was allowed to lapse. It came back online about 36 hours later after the funding was restored. UNL has operated the center for nearly four decades, using the weather and climate data for various tools employed by farmers and ranchers.

articles.title: New Nature Water Study Reveals Worldwide Aridification and Its Impending
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Aridification threatens 40% of Earth's surface and 2.3 billion people. It's a global environmental challenge that demands urgent scientific and policy attention. In the U.S., the Central Valley and the Great Plains are facing unprecedented water scarcity. It threatens not only crop yields but also the management of water resources vital for domestic consumption and ecosystem health.

articles.title: Ecuador Shaken: Earthquake Disrupts Lives and Infrastructure
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A 6.3 magnitude earthquake hit the coast of Ecuador, inflicting injuries on at least 20 people and damaging buildings in the city of Esmeraldas. The possibility of a tsunami was ruled out. President Daniel Noboa assured citizens on social media that shelters would be set up and aid delivered. Two major oil pipelines resumed operation after a temporary halt, though the Esheraldas Refinery is still closed for safety checks.

articles.title: Leading by example: how the rich and powerful can inspire more climate action
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: A majority of people agree that we need to drastically change the way we live and how society operates to address climate change. Another study involving more than 130,000 people across 125 countries found that 69% said they would change their lifestyle to address the problem.

articles.title: NC: 5M CUBIC YARDS OF HELENE DEBRIS CLEARED
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit Asheville, North Carolina. Officials say more work needs to be done to repair the damage caused by Helene, but much progress has been made since the hurricane hit.    .  Â   komnostatsionews.com

articles.title: NETHERLANDS PROTEST GOVERNMENT
articles.author: 요시샘의 미래를 바꾸는 돈 공부
articles.summary: Greenpeace Netherlands activists and people from the Caribbean diaspora rally at the start of a Council of Ministers meeting in The Hague, 25 April 2025. In front of the Catshuis, the Prime Minister's official residence, the activists displayed banners reading 'See you in court' and 'Climate case Bonaire'.

articles.title: Summer Siege
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: For the third summer in a row, India is experiencing prolonged heatwaves and record-breaking temperatures across major urban centers. Poorly ventilated concrete buildings, asphalt roads, and a severe lack of green cover have turned India's cities into pressure cookers during the summer months. Slums and informal housing, where more than 100 million urban Indians reside, are most vulnerable to heatstroke and dehydration. Few Indian cities have a working Heat Action Plan.

articles.title: Increasing number of fires across Ottawa in last five years
articles.author: Special to the Citizen
articles.summary: There were 1,408 fires in Ottawa in 2024, up from 1,304 in 2023. The increase is due to population growth, new construction and extreme weather. The downtown area is more at risk. Fire services were called to 34 more fires in multi-residential units last year compared to 2023, the fire chief said.

articles.title: News4 First Alert Weather Extra: Solar Noon Sun Angle
articles.summary: Zack Webster looks at the change over time of the sun's highest daily point in the sky and what it means for the weather in the U.S. He explains to Zack Webster what this means for our weather and the weather forecast for the next few days.

articles.title: Climate and environment updates: Climate change primary driver of biodiversity loss
articles.summary: For the first time, a study finds climate change is the main driver of biodiversity loss in the United States. The government organization responsible for forecasting hurricanes set a new record for forecast track accuracy in 2024. The recent budget and staffing cuts by the Trump administration could jeopardize this progress.

articles.title: Modern technology does not make species go extinct
articles.author: Lu Staff
articles.summary: Green activists blame modern technology for extinction and species loss. Primitive humans wiped out countless species, while many species have made comebacks in the modern technological world. Last 50,000 years saw about 90 genera of large mammals go extinct, amounting to over 70 percent of America's largest species and over 90 percent of Australia's. Wild animals are coming back in rich areas of the world.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Mass Coral Bleaching Fake News Again', By Paul Homewood
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: 77% of the world's coral reefs are affected by bleaching, mainly due to warming ocean waters amid human-caused climate change. It's the largest and fourth mass global bleaching on record and is impacting both hemispheres. New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Germany and France have pledged $30 million to the U.N. fund for coral reefs established in 2020.

articles.title: CNHI SPECIAL REPORT: Data show Earth continues to get hotter
articles.author: William Bowman CNHI News
articles.summary: 2024 was the warmest year on record, according to the World Meteorological Organization. The last 10 years, from 2015 to 2024, are the 10 hottest in recorded history, which dates back to the mid-19th century. In the United States, the hottest years have all been recorded since 1998, with 2024 the hottest ever measured.

articles.title: Sea temperatures around Korean Peninsula rise more than twice global average
articles.author: Ahn Kwang-ho
articles.summary: Sea surface temperatures in the waters surrounding the Korean Peninsula have risen at more than twice the global average. The East Sea saw the largest increase, followed by the West Sea and the South Sea. The marine ecosystem is deteriorating, including the worst aquaculture losses last year since 2012.

articles.title: Climate Depot's Morano: Bill Gates Through Harvard Funding ‘Radical, Risky' Global Warming Experiments
articles.author: Jeff Poor
articles.summary: Marc Morano warned of 'risky' experiments conducted by Harvard University and bankrolled by billionaire Bill Gates in the name of global warming. He compared the efforts to injecting pollution back into the atmosphere. Morano thinks it's a scare tactic to convince people to support the Green New Deal or Net Zero.

articles.title: Scientists say NOAA cuts by Trump undermine improvements in hurricane forecasts
articles.author: Greg Allen
articles.summary: Trump administration wants to cut funding for NOAA's weather and climate research programs. Hundreds of NOAA employees have been fired. Andy Hazelton, a physical scientist with NOAA in Miami, lost his job this month. He worked to help understand, track and forecast hurricanes at NOAA's Environmental Modeling Center.

articles.title: Former NFL star Adrian Peterson facing DWI charges
articles.summary: Today is cloudy with showers. High 79F. Low 59F. Winds are light and variable. Rainfall is expected to be over 60% in the coming hours.   For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, or click here.

articles.title: Gull central
articles.summary: Red-billed gulls gather on rocks below Taiaroa Head lighthouse in New Zealand. Their numbers have risen 6-10% annually since 1992 on the Otago Peninsula, which has led to a three- or four-fold increase in the local population.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Wrong, New York Times, Climate Change Isn't Disrupting Blood Supplies' By Anthony Watts
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: The New York Times claims that global warming is threatening the world's blood supply due to extreme weather events. There is no scientific evidence that CO-driven climate change is causing a new global blood crisis. The article mentions Hurricane Helene and California wildfires causing canceled blood drives, but there is no evidence that such events are caused by climate change.

articles.title: Follow the Science! New Study Shows Earth's Had Centuries of Warming, Cooling Cycles
articles.author: Amy Curtis
articles.summary: There's a 450,000-year-old study that shows carbon dioxide has no role in earth's climate cycles. The earth has been cooling for a couple thousand years and warming for 2,000 years. There is no global average temperature. The environmental movement is a giant watermelon: green on the outside, red on the inside.

articles.title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR: Climate change continues to be our biggest threat
articles.author: Jamie Swift
articles.summary: Election day is on Monday. This time, we vote just after Earth Day and Earth Week. The biggest peril we face is catastrophic climate breakdown. By the time my granddaughter Nora gets to be my age, the end of the 21st century will be in sight. Earth Week's Kingston theme is Our Power/Our Planet.

articles.title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR: Climate change continues to be our biggest threat
articles.author: Jamie Swift
articles.summary: Election day is on Monday. This time, we vote after Earth Day and Earth Week. The biggest peril we face isn't who occupies the White House or the cost of living here in one of the world's richest countries, but catastrophic climate breakdown. By the time Nora gets to be my age, the end of the 21st century will be in sight.

articles.title: Pollen is hitting the Northeast and South hard - and experts say allergy season is lasting longer
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: The spring allergy season in the Northeast is going to last 180 days longer than usual due to climate change. The freeze-free growing season between 1970 and 2024 was found to have extended by 20 days in 87 percent of the 198 cities they analyzed since 1970. The Northwest and Southwest have experienced the largest average change, increasing by 24 and 20 days respectively.

articles.title: UK scientists are about to attempt to dim the Sun
articles.author: Rebecca Whittaker
articles.summary: British scientists could experiment with techniques to block sunlight as part of a £50 million government funded scheme to combat global warming. The project will be funded by the Advanced Research and Invention Agency, known as ARIA. ARIA has been given £800 million of taxpayers' money to use over the next four years.

articles.title: Column: Cuts to NOAA will make Florida less safe
articles.author: J.P. BROOKER
articles.summary: There are less than two months until the start of the hurricane season. The Trump administration plans to cut NOAA's budget for weather and climate research. The cuts will reduce NOAA's ability to deliver this essential public service and will make Floridians and Americans less safe. NOAA provides accurate information about approaching hurricanes.

articles.title: Yes, Your Friends and Neighbors Want to Talk to You About Climate Change
articles.author: John R. Platt
articles.summary: According to studies, 80-89% of people want the world's governments to take stronger action against climate change. However, not enough people are talking about it, especially in the media. People don't hear enough people talking about climate change, so they don't talk about it themselves. This is a negative feedback loop that perpetuates 'climate silence'. The paper suggests several ways to break this cycle.

articles.title: Hailstorm destroys Kashmir apple orchards
articles.summary: A hailstorm destroyed apple orchards in Kashmir. The area is central to India's apple production. The orchard that had been in the family for three generations has been destroyed. The landslides have blocked major transportation routes, delaying the movement of supplies and emergency services. Some families have lost their homes, stored produce and livestock.

articles.title: World Penguin Day 2025 Date and Significance: Everything To Know About the Day That Calls For the Protection and Conservation of Penguins
articles.author: Meera
articles.summary: World Penguin Day 2025 falls on Friday, April 25. The date aligns with the northward migration of Adélie penguins in Antarctica. The penguin population is declining due to threats like climate change, overfishing, pollution, and habitat degradation. Penguins spend half their lives on land and the other half in the sea. The largest living penguin species is the emperor penguin.

articles.title: Letter: Plan strategy to fight climate change
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Clark County created a Community Advisory Group with 20 members to recommend goals and policies for emissions reduction in 2024. Their unanimous consensus is posted on the county website. New buildings should be EV ready and solar ready. Maximize energy efficiency. Electrify everything if possible. Allow people to live near work and allow mixed-use development.

articles.title: Top 5 fascinating facts about penguins on World Penguin Day
articles.author: Gayathri Kallukaran
articles.summary: Today is World Penguin Day. Penguins are famous for their resilience, adaptability and their role in the animal kingdom. Penguins live in a wide range of environments, from tropical islands to rocky coastal areas. They have been around 30 million years old and evolved from flightless birds. They use their flippers to propel themselves through the water with remarkable speed and agility.

articles.title: Public meeting will include information on potential flood risks
articles.author: Staff Reporters
articles.summary: The Vulnerability Assessment Project is an initiative aimed at safeguarding the unincorporated areas of Okaloosa County against environmental risks, including rising sea levels and flooding. The meeting will take place from 5:30-7 p.m. Wednesday, April 30 at Warriors Hall, 201 Stillwell Blvd., Crestview.

articles.title: Brits warned to cover up and stay indoors as rarely-seen yellow glowing ball in the sky threatens to raise temperatures to *checks notes* 75°F (possible nsfw content on page)
articles.summary: It's 10°C/18°F in Fabove. The average temperature for April is 14°C / 57°F. Most of our housing is built to keep heat in and barely anyone has AC, so it's kind of newsworthy for us.

articles.title: STOSSEL: Living hell?
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: John Stossel's new video covers four myths about climate change. It's not true that climate change is worsening droughts, wildfires, sea level rise and coral reefs are disappearing. Good news doesn't grab headlines and research funding and grants, so they keep reporting bad news.

articles.title: The Green Movement and Climate Change Discussed
articles.author: Colette Gjermundson
articles.summary: The Cornwall Alliance for the Stewardship of Creation is a 20-year-old think tank of natural scientists, economists, policy experts, theologians, philosophers and leaders who are Evangelical Christian scholars. Cal Beisner is founder, chairman and president of the Cornwall Alliance. Beisner holds a Ph.D. in Scottish History from the University of St. Andrews. The green movement is rooted in a 1798 book titled, 'An Essay On (the Principle of) Population' written by late 18th century/early 19th century pastor and self-taught economist, Thomas Robert Malthus.

articles.title: 'Polynya effect': Scientists discover Switzerland-sized hole in the middle of Antarctica
articles.author: Subhadra Srivastava
articles.summary: The polynya may affect global ocean circulation and climate. It influences the movement of heat and carbon dioxide between ocean and atmosphere. It also contributes to deep-water formation, which is key to the global thermohaline circulation. It is also potentially accelerating climate change.

articles.title: ​Meteorology minister urges caution during rainy season; Warns of forecasting flaws​
articles.summary: Thor Chetha is the Minister of Water Resources and Meteorology. He is opening the 24th ASEAN Climate Outlook Forum (ASEANCOF-24) in Phnom Penh on April 24. The forum was hosted by the Cambodia government from April 22 to 25. It included training sessions and technical meetings focused on climate science.

articles.title: Tembisa Youth Lead the Way in Green Action with WESSA
articles.author: Nothando Mthembu
articles.summary: WESSA's youth champions and volunteers cleaned up Winnie Mandela Secondary School and the surrounding community in Tembisa, South Africa last week. They collected 47 tons of waste and planted 10 indigenous trees. It was World Penguin Day for Africa's Best and Only.

articles.title: Ancient camp shows how humans adapted to extreme cold in Europe
articles.author: Taylor Mitchell Brown
articles.summary: Reindeer fur would have helped ancient humans endure the climate of the last glacial maximum. An open-air site in Austria was occupied by humans during the coldest part of the Glacial Maximum, when reindeer's fur might have helped them survive.

articles.title: The generation that can save the Ogallala Aquifer
articles.author: Nick Rex
articles.summary: Jared Faurot's blue jeans are getting sprayed under the drip hose sprinklers. This is the third story in a continuing series about the impact of climate change in the United States and the role of humans in that change.    .

articles.title: At the Bruce Museum, a Climate Change Exhibit Inspired by Alaska
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Daniel Ksepka is curator of a new display at the Bruce Museum. Alaska is 'on the front line' of global warming, he says, because it's a source of climate change research. The display will be on display until the end of the year.

articles.title: G20 discussions focus on trade, innovation, and resilience to unlock Africa's agricultural potential
articles.author: Wandile Sihlobo
articles.summary: The discussions within the G20 Agricultural Working Group are pointing to a promising direction for global agricultural growth and food security, particularly for the African continent. South Africa has set four G20 agricultural priorities: promotion of policies and investments that can lead to improved food and nutrition security, empowering youth and women to participate in agrifood systems, fostering innovation and the transfer of useful technologies in agricultural industries, building climate resilience for sustainable food production, and improving global food security through trade.

articles.title: Greece to Deploy Record Number of Firefighters Ahead of Wildfire Season
articles.author: Filio Kontrafouri
articles.summary: Greece is preparing to confront another wildfire season by deploying a record number of firefighters and 80 drones with thermal cameras. Greece has earmarked some 2 billion euros ($2.3 billion) to buy new aircraft, meteorological stations and drones to improve its capabilities against wildfires.

articles.title: Study uncovers troubling fallout from harm caused by major companies: 'Every delay ... will burden future generations'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: In 2024, the MIT Climate Portal estimated that by the year 2300, the seas could rise 10 meters (33 feet) or more. According to a recent study from the Union of Concerned Scientists, nearly one to two of those feet could be attributed to past pollution from fossil fuel and cement producers up through 2020. The study's co-authors aim to hold the Carbon Majors accountable for their past emissions.

articles.title: Scientists deploy high-speed drones to observe critical issue in extreme locations: 'We'll be able to continuously monitor'
articles.author: Cody Januszko
articles.summary: Scientists will test high-speed drones in Greenland in May to see if the technology can provide crucial data about melting ice sheets. The project is supported by £2 million (more than $2.6 million) from the Advanced Research and Invention Agency. The data is important for predicting various elements of our changing climate.

articles.title: ADB reports $2 billion annual losses for Pakistan due to climate disasters
articles.summary: Pakistan suffers over $2 billion in annual losses due to climate-related disasters. The Asian Development Bank signed a $500 million loan agreement with Pakistan in 2024. The ADB is also supporting Pakistan's social protection programs with a $330 million commitment. The total financial support for Pakistan now amounts to $20.8 billion.

articles.title: New climate change scenario looks at colder weather for the Netherlands
articles.summary: The Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management is investigating a different climate change scenario in which the weather in the Netherlands might become colder instead of warmer. It has to do with possible changes in the Atlantic Gulf Stream. The most likely scenario is still that it will become warmer, but new climate models show that the Gulf Stream is weakening.

articles.title: The real cost of climate change: Shocking report reveals how just 111 companies have cost the world $28 TRILLION in climate damage
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Just 111 companies have cost the world $28 trillion (£21 trillion) in climate damage since the early 1990s. Saudi Aramco is responsible for $2.05 trillion in global economic losses from intensifying extreme heat. Russian energy company Gazprom and American oil and gas giant Chevron are also culpable. ExxonMobil, BP (British Petroleum), Shell, National Iranian Oil Co., Pemex, Coal India and the British Coal Corporation are in the top 10 list.

articles.title: Wilson Creek closed as NCDOT makes hurricane repairs to Brown Mountain Beach Road
articles.author: Xavier Martin
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene recovery efforts are taking place on Wilson Creek. People are asked to avoid travel along Brown Mountain Beach Road. The road is open, but the N.C. Department of Transportation is making critical road repairs. The U.S. Forest Service has closed the Wilson Creek Day Use Area and Harper Creek Falls to aid with recovery efforts.

articles.title: Global Coral Bleaching Event Is 'Biggest To Date,' Affecting 84% Of All Reefs, New Report Finds
articles.author: Sean Breslin
articles.summary: Warming global temperatures are having a catastrophic effect on the planet's coral reefs. 84% of the world's reefs have been impacted by a bleaching event that started in 2023 and remains ongoing. Coral reefs are home to 25% of all marine species and play an important role in the ecosystem.

articles.title: Lucky number seven: There are big challenges
articles.author: Helena Rivers
articles.summary: In recent years, the UK has seen heatwaves and flooding break records with increasing regularity. It's hard to remember a time when this wasn't the case, but it barely registers each time it happens now. It used to, but now it doesn't.

articles.title: Media Update-3: United Nations Pakistan, 24 April 2025 (United Nations in Pakistan)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The United Nations and Pakistan warn about climate change in a press release issued on 24 April 25 April 2025. The release was issued by Breadcrumb Home, Press Centre and Joint Press Release of WHO and Republican Press Association of Pakistan (RPA). The release is titled Media Update-3.

articles.title: A Visit to Alaska Inspires a Climate Change Exhibit in Connecticut
articles.author: Shivani Vora
articles.summary: Daniel Ksepka, curator of science at the Bruce Museum in New York, visited Fairbanks, Alaska, in May 2022 for a research project on fossil birds. He was impressed by the landscape of the city's drunken forest. He is concerned about the impact of global warming on the Alaskan landscape. The Bruce's exhibition 'On Thin Ice: Alaska's Warming Wilderness' opened March 6 and will be on view until Oct. 19. The animals in the exhibit represent the wildlife that inhabits Alaska's wilderness.

articles.title: COMMENTARY: Want money and attention; you need to scare people
articles.summary: There are four myths about climate change. The last 50 years have generally been wetter than average, so there's been no increase in drought. The real cause of wildfires is land management. Sea level rise is occurring, but it's been slow and people can adapt to it.

articles.title: Spanish seafood exports threatened as US tariffs, global port rivalries collide
articles.summary: Javier Touza, president of Vigo's fishing shipowner cooperative, has warned that the convergence of these two developments could have long-term, destabilizing effects in Vigo, Spain. María Feijóo is the author of this article.

articles.title: Shifting Seasons: Wildfire activity and our warming world
articles.author: John Carroll
articles.summary: Last year was a record year for wildfires in Oregon, as 1.93 million acres were burned. Dr. Erica Fleischman, director of the Oregon Climate Change Research Institute and professor at Oregon State University, says the world is becoming warmer and drier, the western U.S. is becoming a drier place, and the population is increasing.

articles.title: Will the Netherlands have colder weather due to climate change?
articles.author: Robin Pascoe
articles.summary: The Dutch infrastructure ministry commissioned scientists to investigate the impact of global warming on the Gulf Stream on the Netherlands. The Gulf Stream brings warmer water to the Netherlands and north-western Europe. The most likely scenario is still that it will become warmer, but the newest climate models suggest changes to it are becoming more likely.

articles.title: Nigeria: Aramco, Gazprom, Chevron Top As Oil Firms Cause $28tn in Climate Damage
articles.author: Emmanuel Addeh
articles.summary: Extreme heat caused by emissions from 111 fossil fuel companies cost an estimated $28 trillion between 1991 and 2020. Saudi Aramco was liable in climate damage to the tune of $2.05 trillion, Gazprom: $2 trillion, Chevron: $1.98 trillion, ExxonMobil: $ 1.91 trillion, and BP:$1.45 trillion. The five companies constituted about a third of the total cost.

articles.title: US Aid Cuts Threaten Indo-Pacific Malaria Surge
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: On World Malaria Day, 25 April Pacific Friends of Global Health and the Australian Global Health Alliance are raising the alarm over the potential for a resurgence of malaria throughout the Indo-Pacific region. US government cut 90% of funding for global public health programs. WHO predicts an additional 15 million malaria cases and 107,000 deaths this year.

articles.title: Living hell?
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: 'Climate change will make earth a living hell!' claims popular astrophysicist Neil DeGrasse Tyson. You must be a subscriber to read the content. You can subscribe to the Lakeland Times online only by paying $45 a year.    For more information, visit the Lakelands Times Online Store.

articles.title: Hot March breaks Victorian records
articles.author: Djembe Archibald
articles.summary: Victoria has seen a hotter than average autumn. The Bureau of Meteorology says winter won't be much different from the previous year's.    for Victoria, Australia's winter is expected to be warmer than usual, according to the bureau's forecast.

articles.title: Climate: What early warning system means to aviation, agric, economy
articles.author: Tribune
articles.summary: Tribune Online explains what early warning system means to aviation, agriculture and economy. The weather patterns are changing due to climate change, but people don't notice it until the heat season is over. The rainy season will also take a different turn due to the climate change.

articles.title: Kenya Loses Sh870 Billion Annually to Climate Change, Dr. Kalua Green Says Warning of Missed Green Goals
articles.author: Contributor
articles.summary: Kenya loses up to Sh870 billion every year due to climate change. Without urgent action, Kenya could lose Sh15 trillion over the next 15 years. President William Ruto has an ambitious plan to plant 15 billion trees by 2032. Dr. Kalua Green, a renowned environmentalist, has launched the Institute for Sustainability and Climate Action at the International Leadership University.

articles.title: EIB's know-how on the climate resilience of Greek ports
articles.summary: The initiative focuses on conducting Climate Change Risk and Vulnerability Assessments for the ports of Volos, Alexandroupolis and Patras. The EIB Advisory Service will support the respective port authorities in identifying and addressing climate change-related natural hazards that may affect port infrastructure and operations.

articles.title: UCLA Study Reveals Ways to Combat Climate Apathy
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Presenting continuous climate data in binary form significantly increases people's ability to see the impact of climate change. Making an emotional connection to the loss of local traditions may also help overcome climate apathy. People adjust "disturbingly fast" to gradual temperature increases. People are mentally adapting to the negative changes in our environment.

articles.title: New techniques uncover how climate ‘upheaval' led to the extinction of Australia's giant kangaroos
articles.summary: Giant prehistoric kangaroos died when climate upheaval turned lush Australian rainforest into desert 300,000 years ago. Scientists recreated the foraging habits of one population by matching long-lived chemicals from fossilised teeth to recently unearthed rocks. The techniques could be used to better understand the disappearance of Australia's megafauna.

articles.title: Will Australia succumb to anti-Israel populism as elections near?
articles.author: ROMY LEIBLER/THE MEDIA LINE
articles.summary: Australia goes to the polls on May 3. Since October 7, 2023, Australia has experienced an outburst of antisemitism. The ruling Labor Party has abandoned its traditional support for Israel and adopted pro-Palestinian positions. In the forthcoming election, the incumbent Labor party is offering more of the same to appease the Muslim vote. The Liberal-National Coalition has promised to return Australia to its traditional supports for Israel. In many hotly contested seats, including the seat held by Labor's Jewish attorney general, Mark Dreyfus, Labor is entering into deals with the Greens party to exchange preferences.

articles.title: Albany is one of the fastest-warming cities in the U.S. What is the impact, and what can it do better?
articles.author: Lucille Lannigan
articles.summary: Albany's average annual temperature rose 5.1 degrees from 1970 to 2024. The average temperature rise of the 242 U.S. cities analyzed was 2.9 degrees. The city has a poverty rate more than double Georgia's and a population that is 85% African American. The population has declined by almost 30,000 since 2000.

articles.title: Minister sees serious climate threats to GB
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Gilgit-Baltistan is on the frontline of climate change. The initiatives taken under the GLOF-II Project deserve recognition for empowering communities to respond effectively to climate threats, according to the minister for climate change Senator Musadik Malik. Gilgit is witnessing increasing incidents of glacial melting and glaciers lakes outburst floods.

articles.title: Pinellas County leaders gather for 'State of the Beaches" conversation after devastating storms
articles.author: Aaron Mesmer
articles.summary: Leaders from Gulfport, Indian Shores, Madeira Beach, Redington Beach and Treasure Island gathered for a "State of the Beaches" conversation on Thursday. They agreed that FEMA and permitting issues have caused frustration for residents, but things are trending upwards nearly a year after the storms.

articles.title: ‘Without rules, countries just game the system': Climate report finds major economies overstating forest carbon absorption, risking emission goals
articles.summary: Major economies are overstating how much carbon their forests can absorb in a climate accounting fudge, according to new research. The assessment singled out Brazil and Australia. It warned a lack of rules around accounting for forests and other land-based carbon sinks meant countries could 'game the system' when reporting their national greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Warming rivers threaten fly fishing industry in California, across country
articles.author: David
articles.summary: As climate change continues to warm our rivers, the pressure is growing on California's cold-water trout. 87% of rivers studied across the U.S. and Europe are warming, with 70% losing oxygen. Fewer fish to catch is hurting the local fishing-tourism economy.

articles.title: Climate change intensifying country's malaria crisis: Health minister
articles.summary: On World Malaria Day, WHO and Pakistan's Ministry of National Health Services have issued an urgent call to action. Climate change is intensifying the country's malaria crisis. In 2023 alone, Pakistan recorded 2.7 million cases, a sharp increase from just under 400,000 in 2021.

articles.title: Report highlights risks of using forests to meet climate targets
articles.author: Hassaan F Khan
articles.summary: Major economies are overstating how much carbon their forests can absorb in a climate accounting fudge that could allow them to use more fossil fuels, according to new research. The assessment singled out Brazil and Australia. It warned a lack of rules around accounting for forests and other land-based carbon sinks meant countries could 'game the system' when reporting their national greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.summary: Sherry Listgarten is writing a blog about climate change. She studied math and neurobiology on the east coast before moving to California in 1987 for grad school in computer science. She retired from the tech industry a few years ago to better align her time with her priorities.

articles.title: Weather Insider: 2025 Minimum Antarctic Sea Ice Extent
articles.author: Spencer Blum
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice probably reached its summer minimum extent on March 1st, about five days later than usual. This ties with 2022 and 2024 for the second-lowest ice extent on record. This year's extent is 860 thousand square kilometers lower than the median, but 73 thousand square miles more than the record low set back in 2023.

articles.title: World's biggest firms caused $28 tn in climate change: Study
articles.summary: The world's biggest corporations have caused $28 trillion in climate damage, according to a Dartmouth College study. More than half of the figure comes from 10 fossil fuel providers: Saudi Aramco, Gazprom, Chevron, ExxonMobil, BP, Shell, National Iranian Oil Co., Pemex, Coal India and the British Coal Corporation.

articles.title: Barnacle goose invasion threatens farmers' livelihoods
articles.author: Iceland Monitor
articles.summary: There is a sharp rise in the barnacle goose population in Southeast Iceland. The birds compete for grazing land and consume large portions of cultivated fields. It poses a growing threat to local farmers, as the birds increasingly compete for vital grazing land, and consume crops.

articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: Neil DeGrasse Tyson claims that climate change will make the earth a living hell. John Stossel doesn't believe him. The media say that all Arctic ice will soon melt away and Polar bears are dying off. Global warming causes food shortages. They are not true.

articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: An Austrian site occupied by humans from around 24,000 to 20,000 years ago documents a switch towards hunting reindeer for their fur. People may have hunted them because of harsh winters during the last glacial period, which may have helped them to survive.

articles.title: Navy secretary cancels Biden-era climate change policy
articles.summary: Navy Secretary John Phelan has canceled the Navy's Climate Action 2030 program. The program was enacted by the Biden administration in 2022 to improve the service's energy efficiency. It committed the Navy to reduce its overall emissions by 65% by 2030 and reach net-zero emissions by 2050.
